item.title: Gifts, Gadgets and Greece: Inside a Huawei Lobbying Campaign
item.description: Leaked internal messages detail efforts by the Chinese tech giant to court Greek officials and fight an American-led effort against its technology.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Eliza Triantafillou
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mark Harris; Photographs by Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times, Aly Song/Reuters, Fabian Sommer/Getty Images

item.title: A Silicon Valley Supergroup Is Coming Together to Create an A.I. Device
item.description: OpenAI’s Sam Altman, the former Apple designer Jony Ive and SoftBank’s Masayoshi Son are teaming up to develop a device that could replace the smartphone.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle and Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: OpenAI’s Sam Altman has been discussing building an A.I. device with Jony Ive, Apple’s former design guru.

item.title: IBM Tries to Ease Customers’ Qualms About Using Generative A.I.
item.description: The company will assume the legal risk of businesses that use its A.I. systems and will publish the technology’s underlying data.
item.dc:creator: Steve Lohr
item.media:credit: Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Twelve years ago, IBM’s Watson’s A.I. system beat top competitors on “Jeopardy!”

item.title: Meet the A.I. Jane Austen: Meta Weaves A.I. Throughout Its Apps
item.description: Meta introduced artificially intelligent characters based on Jane Austen, Snoop Dogg and others into Instagram, Facebook and WhatsApp, as the race to lead the technology heats up.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, introduced a slew of A.I. products at the company’s Silicon Valley headquarters on Wednesday.

item.title: Random New Test News
item.description: Random New Test News
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Natalija Gormalova
item.media:description: Random New Test News

item.title: Test News NEW Update
item.description: This is a NEW test news
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Natalija Gormalova
item.media:description: This is a NEW test news from RSS feed

item.title: The Gamble: Can Genetically Modified Mosquitoes End Disease?
item.description: Working on a remote island, scientists think they can use genetic engineering to block a malaria-carrying species of mosquito from spreading the disease — and do it in just a few months. But governments are wary.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Natalija Gormalova
item.media:description: A female Anopheles mosquito, marked with fluorescent powder, under a microscope in a field laboratory on the island of Príncipe. Only female mosquitoes bite humans, and thus spread disease.

item.title: Federal Lawsuit Accuses Tesla of Racial Discrimination
item.description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed a lawsuit accusing the carmaker of mistreating Black employees at its factory in California.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Justin Kaneps for The New York Times
item.media:description: The assembly line at the Tesla factory in Fremont, Calif.

item.title: China Uses ‘Deceptive’ Methods to Sow Disinformation, U.S. Says
item.description: The accusations reflect worry in Washington that China’s information operations pose a growing security challenge to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Joshua Roberts/Reuters
item.media:description: The State Department reports that China is using various methods, including buying stakes in media organizations and using social media, to spread propaganda.

item.title: Quebec Lures $5 Billion Battery Factory for Electric Cars
item.description: The Canadian government matched financial incentives available in the U.S. to attract the investment from Northvolt, a Swedish company.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing

item.title: ¿En qué consiste la demanda a Amazon de la FTC?
item.description: La agencia de protección a los consumidores de Estados Unidos asegura que el gigante de internet usó su poder monopólico para aumentar precios y perjudicar a sus competidores
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran para The New York Times
item.media:description: Gran parte del poder de Amazon radica en su mercado en línea, a veces conocido como “tienda de todo” por la variedad de productos que vende y la rapidez con la que los entrega.

item.title: Ilia Calderón’s Questions at GOP Debate Catch Candidates Off-Guard
item.description: The Univision anchor, one of three moderators, caught some candidates off-guard with questions on immigration and hate crimes.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Etienne Laurent/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Ilia Calderón, right, at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, Calif., on Wednesday.

item.title: Sony’s PlayStation Chief to Retire Next Year
item.description: Jim Ryan, who has been with the company for nearly 30 years, has led one of the most dominant businesses in the video game industry.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Alex Wong/Getty Images
item.media:description: Jim Ryan, the chief executive of Sony Interactive Entertainment since 2019, will retire in March.

item.title: The New ChatGPT Can ‘See’ and ‘Talk.’ Here’s What It’s Like.
item.description: The image-recognition feature could have many uses, and the voice feature is even more intriguing.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
item.media:description: ChatGPT’s new features are part of an industrywide push toward “multimodal” A.I. systems that can handle text, photos and videos.

item.title: To Bring Socializing Back to Social Networks, Apps Try A.I. Imagery
item.description: Instagram, Facebook, Snapchat and several newcomers are betting on artificial intelligence to rejuvenate the fun, interactivity and whimsy of creating and sharing images.
item.dc:creator: Yiwen Lu
item.media:credit: Myuri Thiruna and Jennifer Lee
item.media:description: Selfie images generated by Myuri Thiruna and a friend with artificial intelligence on the Can of Soup app.

item.title: With Meta’s Quest 3, Mixed Reality Is Here. So Now What?
item.description: The new $500 headset lets people see the outside world while immersed in virtual reality. The benefits are to be determined.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen
item.media:credit: Derek Abella

item.title: Lina Khan vs. Jeff Bezos: This Is Big Tech’s Real Cage Match
item.description: The chair of the Federal Trade Commission wants to disrupt Amazon, whose founder built a trillion-dollar firm by disrupting retail.
item.dc:creator: David Streitfeld
item.media:credit: Photographs by Pablo Martinez Monsivais/Associated Press; Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federal Trade Commission filed an antitrust lawsuit against Amazon, pitting the agency’s chair, Lina Khan, against the company’s founder, Jeff Bezos, in a long-awaited confrontation.

item.title: E.U. Law Sets the Stage for a Clash Over Disinformation
item.description: The law, aimed at forcing social media giants to adopt new policies to curb harmful content, is expected to face blowback from Elon Musk, who owns X.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Jakub Gavlak/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Robert Fico, left, heads Slovakia’s SMER party. As the country heads toward an election on Saturday, it has been inundated with disinformation and other harmful content on social media sites.

item.title: Biden Administration Plans to Bring Back ‘Net Neutrality’ Rules
item.description: The head of the Federal Communications Commission said the government needed to protect open access to the “essential infrastructure of modern life.”
item.dc:creator: Steve Lohr
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images
item.media:description: Jessica Rosenworcel, the Federal Communications Commission Chairwoman. Earlier open internet rules, known as net neutrality, prohibited broadband internet suppliers from blocking or slowing online services.

item.title: FTC Says Amazon Used These Tactics to Undermine Competition
item.description: In a lawsuit filed on Tuesday, the Federal Trade Commission said the internet giant used its monopoly power to stifle competition and raise prices.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Much of Amazon’s power comes from its online marketplace, sometimes known as an “everything store” for the range of products it sells and the speed with which it delivers them.

item.title: Top Apple Executive Defends Favoring Google on iPhones
item.description: Eddy Cue, a longtime executive at the company, said Apple’s multibillion-dollar deals with Google were driven by quality, not money.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang and Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images
item.media:description: Eddy Cue, Apple’s senior vice president of services, arriving at a federal courthouse in Washington, D.C.

item.title: For Amazon’s Andy Jassy, a Cleanup Job Just Got a Lot Bigger
item.description: The F.T.C. accused the internet giant of protecting an online retail monopoly and forcing higher prices onto consumers.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Victor Llorente for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andy Jassy, here at the 2022 DealBook conference, replaced Jeff Bezos as Amazon’s chief executive two years ago.

item.title: FTC Sues Amazon, Accusing Company of Illegal Online Retail Monopoly
item.description: The Federal Trade Commission and 17 states sued Amazon, saying its conduct in its online store and services to merchants illegally stifled competition.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Joe Buglewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Much of Amazon’s power comes from its online marketplace, sometimes known as an “everything store” for the range of products it sells and the speed with which it delivers them.

item.title: ‘Unprecedented’ Secrecy in Google Trial as Tech Giants Push to Limit Disclosures
item.description: Efforts to seal testimony have increasingly raised questions as the federal antitrust case enters its third week in court.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant, Cecilia Kang and Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: The case against Google is shaping up to be among the most secretive antitrust trials of the last few decades.

item.title: Can the U.S. Make Solar Panels? This Company Thinks So.
item.description: First Solar kept producing them in Ohio after most of the industry moved to China. President Biden wants many more domestic manufacturers.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Daniel Lozada for The New York Times
item.media:description: First Solar’s factory in Perrysburg, Ohio, has been making solar panels for more than 20 years.

item.title: Nuclear Fusion Breakthrough Gets a Bigger Burst of Laser Energy
item.description: Researchers at the National Ignition Facility during a July firing of 192 lasers improved on a December result, but also ended up with duds in other experiments.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.category: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)
item.media:credit: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
item.media:description: The target bay of the National Ignition Facility at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California.

item.title: The Secret Ingredient of ChatGPT Is Human Advice
item.description: Companies like OpenAI hone their bots using hand-tailored examples from well-educated workers. But is this always for the best?
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Marlena Sloss for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nazneen Rajani, a researcher with the artificial intelligence lab Hugging Face, is among the scientists working to sharpen chatbots using hand-tailored examples from well-educated workers.

item.title: ChatGPT Can Now Respond With Spoken Words
item.description: A new version of OpenAI’s popular chatbot behaves a lot like Siri and Alexa. You can talk to it — and have a conversation.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz, Brian X. Chen and Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Over the next two weeks, OpenAI said, the new version of its chatbot would roll out to everyone who subscribes to ChatGPT Plus.

item.title: Air Force Receives Its First Electric Air Taxi
item.description: Joby Aviation delivered the aircraft, which can carry a pilot and four passengers, to Edwards Air Force Base in California for testing.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Amazon to Invest Up to $4 Billion in A.I. Start-Up Anthropic
item.description: With its investment of up to $4 billion, Amazon is seeking a bigger footprint in A.I. development, one already established by rivals like Microsoft and Google.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Marissa Leshnov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anthropic is seen as one of the most promising of a group of A.I. start-ups, and previously received investment from Google.

item.title: Egg Crack Challenge and Cheese Slice Trick: Are Parents OK?
item.description: With the “cheese slice trick” and the “egg crack challenge,” parents vie for viral recognition — and the illusion of control over their children.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Hess
item.media:credit: Liana Finck

item.title: TV Networks’ Last Best Hope: Boomers
item.description: Viewers have fled prime-time lineups for streaming outlets, with one notable exception: people over 60.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: Simon Bailly

item.title: Netflix Prepares to Send Its Final Red Envelope
item.description: The company’s DVD subscription service is ending this month, bringing to a close an origin story that ultimately upended the entertainment industry.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling and Mark Abramson
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: The Man Who Trapped Us in Databases
item.description: Hank Asher was a drug smuggler with a head for numbers — until he figured out how to turn Americans’ private information into a big business.
item.dc:creator: McKenzie Funk
